title: ARCV Busted!
historical_context: This article discusses the arrest of members of the Association of Really Cruel Viruses (ARCV) in the early 1990s, a time when computer viruses were becoming a significant concern for law enforcement and the tech community.
target_audience: Hackers, security professionals, and those interested in the history of computer crime.
short_summary: The article details the arrest of members of the ARCV by Scotland Yard, primarily due to their involvement in phone phreaking rather than virus writing. It highlights the legal implications and the broader context of computer crime during the early 1990s.
summary: DecimatoR expresses sympathy for the arrested individuals, particularly Apache Warrior and Ice-9, while critiquing the legal system's stance on virus authorship. The article argues that writing code should not be criminalized, contrasting it with the illegal nature of spreading viruses or committing fraud. The narrative serves as a reflection on the evolving landscape of computer crime, illustrating the fine line between creativity in coding and legal repercussions. The piece is a poignant reminder of the challenges faced by early hackers and virus writers in navigating a rapidly changing legal environment.
